item.title: Study identifies 13 genes that increase osteoarthritis risk - R&D World
item.description:
Study Identifies 13 Genes Increasing Osteoarthritis Risk

Publication Date: October 2023 | Source: Cell Genomics

Researchers at the UNC Thurston Arthritis Research Center have identified 13 genes that contribute to osteoarthritis, affecting over 32 million people in the U.S. This discovery aims to guide the development of targeted therapies to prevent disease progression.

  • Researchers pinpointed 13 “high probability risk genes” for osteoarthritis.
  • Nearly half of the risk for osteoarthritis is genetic, according to recent studies.
  • Six of the identified genes were previously unknown.
  • The study was backed by a $2.5 million grant from the National Institute of Arthritis and Musculoskeletal and Skin Diseases.
  • Drug screening studies are being conducted to find compounds that target these genes.
“If we can identify the causal genes, we can use that information to define new genetic targets for therapies for osteoarthritis.” - Dr. Richard F. Loeser, Jr.

This research provides valuable insights into osteoarthritis and could lead to early intervention strategies to combat the disease effectively.

item.title: Bird Flu Is Raising Red Flags Among Health Officials - Johns Hopkins Bloomberg School of Public Health
item.description:
Bird Flu Is Raising Red Flags Among Health Officials

Publication Date: January 6, 2024 | Source: Johns Hopkins Bloomberg School of Public Health

On January 6, Louisiana's Department of Health reported the first U.S. death from H5N1 avian influenza, heightening fears over the virus's potential to mutate and infect humans. Health officials stress the importance of monitoring the situation as cases of H5N1 in humans continue to be documented.

  • The patient had a backyard flock that was exposed to wild birds.
  • 66 confirmed human cases of H5N1 have occurred in the U.S., primarily from poultry farm exposures.
  • Public health experts are monitoring the virus following signs of mutation.
  • The concern of genetic reassortment between seasonal influenza and H5N1 is highlighted.
“We need to double down on our efforts to limit H5N1 transmission among cattle and birds.” - Meghan Davis, DVM, PhD

This situation reflects a larger potential threat to public health, necessitating increased surveillance and precautionary measures.

item.title: Hepatitis E vaccination is effective in an epidemic - Science Daily
item.description:
Hepatitis E Vaccination is Effective in an Epidemic

Publication Date: October 2023 | Source: The Lancet Infectious Diseases

In South Sudan, where hepatitis E outbreaks are common due to contaminated water, a recent study has shown that the two-dose regimen of the hepatitis E vaccine is effective in fighting the disease despite the challenges posed by a 3-dose standard regimen.

  • The study involved collaboration between Médecins Sans Frontières, Johns Hopkins University, the South Sudanese Ministry of Health, WHO, and other organizations.
  • The vaccination campaign targeted over 100,000 people in camps for internally displaced individuals.
  • Results indicated that even after just two doses, the vaccine was effective in reducing hepatitis E cases.
  • Approximately 50,000 deaths worldwide are attributed to hepatitis E annually, with high-risk populations including pregnant women.
  • The WHO has confirmed the effectiveness of the vaccine and approved the creation of a global stockpile for emergencies.
"Our results combined with others helped lead to recent approval by WHO's International Coordinating Group of a stockpile of hepatitis E vaccines for emergencies." - Andrew Azman, Epidemiologist

In conclusion, the study supports the vaccine's use in outbreak situations and showcases the importance of adapting vaccination protocols to address immediate health crises.

item.title: Outbreak of suspected Marburg Virus Disease - United Republic of Tanzania - ReliefWeb
item.description:
Outbreak of Suspected Marburg Virus Disease in Tanzania

Date: 13 January 2025 Source: World Health Organization

On 13 January 2025, the WHO reported an outbreak of suspected Marburg Virus Disease in the Kagera region of Tanzania, with initial reports indicating a high case fatality rate among suspected cases.

  • Six suspected cases were reported, with five fatalities.
  • By 11 January 2025, nine suspected cases were identified, with eight deaths (CFR of 89%).
  • National rapid response teams have been deployed to undertake contact tracing and investigation.
  • The outbreak has raised concerns due to the risk of nosocomial transmission among healthcare workers.
  • The geographic spread poses concerns, particularly near international borders with several neighboring countries.
  • WHO assesses the risk of the outbreak as high nationally but low globally at this stage.

The suspected outbreak thus far involves at least nine suspected cases, including eight deaths, resulting in a high CFR of 89%.

Enhanced surveillance, risk communication, and community engagement are essential to manage this outbreak effectively. WHO advises against travel restrictions with Tanzania.

item.title: BMI by itself isn't an accurate tool to diagnose obesity: Study - The Times of India
item.description:
BMI by itself isn't an accurate tool to diagnose obesity: Study

Date: October 2023

Source: Health Wellness Journal

This article discusses a study that challenges the effectiveness of Body Mass Index (BMI) as a tool for diagnosing obesity.

  • The study suggests BMI alone does not accurately reflect an individual's health.
  • Experts recommend combining BMI with other assessments for a comprehensive view.
  • There is a growing call for more reliable measurement tools in obesity diagnoses.
"BMI is a simplistic measure that doesn't account for muscle mass, fat distribution, and other health markers."

Ultimately, the article emphasizes the need for a multifaceted approach in assessing obesity rather than relying solely on BMI.

item.title: Moderna May Have The Best Shot At A Vaccine For Stomach Flu - Forbes
item.description:
Moderna May Have The Best Shot At A Vaccine For Stomach Flu

Date: Not specified | Source: Forbes

Every year, between 19 and 21 million Americans suffer from gastroenteritis caused by noroviruses. Norovirus infections lead to numerous hospitalizations, and with a recent surge in cases, vaccination efforts are becoming crucial.

  • Norovirus causes hundreds of thousands of ER visits and about 900 deaths annually in the U.S.
  • Moderna is currently at the forefront, utilizing mRNA technology similar to its Covid-19 vaccine.
  • The economic impact of annual norovirus infections is around $60 billion globally.
  • Moderna's norovirus vaccine aims to target three different strains, potentially covering up to 80% of yearly outbreaks.
  • Challenges in vaccine development include the need for effective immunity in the gastrointestinal tract.
“Washing your hands with soap and water is the most important thing in protecting yourself.” - Daniel Kuritzkes

The potential for a successful norovirus vaccine could revolutionize public health and reduce the substantial economic burden of the virus, although challenges remain in vaccine development and testing.

item.title: Norovirus wave in US more than double last year's peak as new strain fuels winter surge: CDC data - India Today
item.description:
Norovirus wave in US more than double last year's peak as new strain fuels winter surge: CDC data

Published On: Jan 15, 2025

Source: indiastodayglobal

Norovirus cases have surged to more than double last year's peak, primarily due to a new strain, GII.17[P17], with the Midwest being the hardest hit. Experts are urging precautions as infection rates rise.

  • Norovirus positivity rate has jumped to nearly 28% during the New Year’s holidays, compared to 13.52% last year.
  • The CDC reports that norovirus is widespread across all U.S. regions, particularly affecting the Midwest from Kansas to Michigan.
  • The new strain, GII.17[P17], is responsible for over 70% of current outbreaks, including incidents on cruise ships.
  • Precautions include frequent handwashing and avoiding contaminated food and water.
“This new strain has caused over 70% of outbreaks this season, and lower immunity to it is believed to be driving the current surge,” experts say.

The current surge in norovirus cases is raising concerns, and CDC recommends following health precautions to mitigate the spread.

item.title: Broken Heart Disease: How heightened stress-levels can weaken heart muscles - The Times of India
item.description:
Broken Heart Disease: How Heightened Stress Levels Can Weaken Heart Muscles

Publication Date: October 17, 2023, Source: Times of India

Heart disease can sometimes be triggered by emotional events, commonly referred to as broken heart syndrome. This article discusses how significant stress can lead to heart muscle weakening.

  • Heightened stress levels can lead to temporary weakening of the heart muscles, mimicking heart attack symptoms.
  • Recent studies indicate a link between emotional trauma and heart health, particularly in vulnerable populations.
  • Symptoms include chest pain, shortness of breath, and other common heart attack indicators.
  • Understanding this phenomenon is crucial for better diagnostic practices in cardiology.
“Understanding the emotional triggers and their physiological impact on the heart is essential for preventing serious complications.”

This article emphasizes the necessity for increased awareness surrounding emotional factors that can affect heart health.

item.title: Addressing the controversial 'O': All you need to know about Ozempic and why it’s trending - The Times of India
item.description:
Addressing the controversial 'O': All you need to know about Ozempic and why it’s trending

Publication Date: (not specified) Source: Times of India

Ozempic is trending due to its growing popularity and discussions around its efficacy and side effects. This article explores why it has become a focal point of conversation.

  • Ozempic is widely used as a weight-loss drug.
  • It is often prescribed for diabetes management.
  • Concerns about its side effects and long-term health implications are rising.
  • The drug has sparked conversations about obesity treatment options.
"Ozempic is changing the landscape of weight management and diabetes treatment, but it comes with both praise and caution."

The rise of Ozempic in public discourse highlights the shifting attitudes toward weight loss drugs and their perceived benefits versus risks.

item.title: Are children getting sick and dying due to chemicals and plastics? Scientists reveal the truth - The Times of India
item.description:
Are Children at Risk from Chemicals and Plastics? Insights from Leading Scientists

Publication Date: Recent | Source: The Guardian

This article discusses the alarming rise in diseases among children, attributed to increasing exposure to synthetic chemicals and plastics, as highlighted by a new study published in the New England Journal of Medicine.

  • Children are more sensitive to chemicals due to physiological factors.
  • Deaths from noncommunicable diseases have drastically increased over the past 50 years.
  • Childhood cancer rates have surged by 35%.
  • One in 36 children is diagnosed with autism.
  • Asthma cases have tripled, and obesity rates have quadrupled.
  • Manufacturing of plastics has increased 50 times since 1950.
“The evidence is so overwhelming and the effects of manufactured chemicals are so disruptive for children, that inaction is no longer an option.” - Daniele Mandrioli

The authors call for urgent global action to reform chemical testing and manufacturing practices to better protect children's health.

item.title: Enjoying more cups of green tea daily reduces dementia brain lesions: Study - The Times of India
item.description:
Enjoying More Cups of Green Tea Daily Reduces Dementia Brain Lesions: Study

Published on: [Publication Date] Source: [Source Name]

This study reveals that daily consumption of green tea correlates with reduced brain lesions associated with dementia, highlighting the potential health benefits of this beverage.

  • Increased daily green tea consumption linked to lower dementia-related brain lesions.
  • Research contributes to the understanding of dietary impacts on cognitive health.
  • Suggests public health policy may benefit from promoting beneficial dietary habits.
“The findings indicate that drinking green tea may play a role in maintaining cognitive function.”

This study underscores the importance of dietary choices in promoting brain health, advocating for wider consumption of green tea.

item.title: Even Low Levels of ctDNA May Be Linked to Recurrence Risk in Early Lung Cancer, Study Finds - The ASCO Post
item.description:
Even Low Levels of ctDNA May Be Linked to Recurrence Risk in Early Lung Cancer, Study Finds

Publication Date: Not specified Source: Nature Medicine

Lung cancer, the second most common cancer in the U.S., has high recurrence rates in early-stage patients. A new study indicates that low levels of circulating tumor DNA (ctDNA) are associated with an increased risk of recurrence in early-stage lung adenocarcinoma, pointing to the potential for personalized genomic testing.

  • The study was based on the TRACERx cohort of 171 patients with early-stage lung cancer.
  • NeXT Personal, a sensitive genomic test, was used to analyze blood samples for ctDNA levels.
  • Results showed that patients with < 80 ppm ctDNA had reduced overall survival.
  • Positive ctDNA detection correlated with a high recurrence risk, even at low levels.
“This study demonstrates the potential of using more sensitive ctDNA tests like NeXT Personal in detecting lung cancer.” - Charles Swanton

The findings underscore the importance of sensitive ctDNA testing for personalizing lung cancer treatment and improving patient outcomes.

item.title: Why letting your dog lick your face can make you seriously ill, reveals study - The Times of India
item.description:
Why letting your dog lick your face can make you seriously ill, reveals study

Publication Date: N/A Source: N/A

This article discusses the findings of a recent study that suggests allowing your dog to lick your face can have serious health implications.

  • The study highlights potential health risks associated with pet saliva.
  • It emphasizes the importance of hygiene practices with pets.
  • Specialists encourage pet owners to be aware of possible infections.
“Pet saliva can carry harmful bacteria that may lead to serious illnesses,” said a leading veterinary expert.

The findings of the study serve as a reminder for pet owners to maintain good hygiene and be cautious about letting pets lick their faces.

item.title: It's possible to erase bad memories; scientists discover how - The Times of India
item.description:
It's Possible to Erase Bad Memories; Scientists Discover How

Publication Date: N/A Source: N/A

This article discusses a groundbreaking study that suggests it's feasible to erase bad memories using targeted scientific techniques, potentially paving the way for new therapeutic methods.

  • Researchers have identified specific neural pathways that can be altered to diminish the impact of negative memories.
  • The study opens up possibilities for treating conditions like PTSD and anxiety disorders.
  • Ethical considerations of memory alteration are discussed, emphasizing the importance of consent and potential unforeseen consequences.
“The ability to modify or erase memories could be revolutionary in the treatment of mental health disorders,” said a lead researcher.

This discovery marks a significant step in neuroscience and psychology, raising questions about the future of memory treatment.

item.title: 10 morning habits to keep the kidneys in good health - The Times of India
item.description:
10 Morning Habits to Keep the Kidneys Healthy

Publication Date: Jan 14, 2025 | Source: Times of India

This article discusses simple yet effective habits to enhance kidney health, emphasizing the importance of routine practices like hydration and balanced meals in maintaining good kidney function.

  • Drink water first thing in the morning to rehydrate.
  • Engage in regular exercise to support kidney health.
  • Consume kidney-friendly foods like berries and leafy greens.
  • Eat a balanced breakfast rich in nutrients.
  • Take probiotics or herbal teas to promote kidney function.
  • Monitor blood sugar levels to protect kidney health.
  • Maintain healthy blood pressure through yoga or meditation.
  • Avoid excessive caffeine intake to prevent dehydration.
  • Practice deep breathing exercises to relieve stress.
  • Limit salt intake to reduce strain on the kidneys.
“Starting your day with healthy habits can significantly boost kidney function.” - TOI Lifestyle Desk

In conclusion, integrating these morning habits can lead to improved kidney health and overall well-being.

item.title: AI reveals key follicle sizes to boost IVF success - News-Medical.Net
item.description:
AI Reveals Key Follicle Sizes to Boost IVF Success

Publication Date: January 14, 2025 | Source: News-Medical

A recent study utilizes explainable artificial intelligence (XAI) to identify follicle sizes important for optimizing outcomes in assisted conception, particularly in vitro fertilization (IVF).

  • One in six couples globally faces infertility, a serious disability as defined by WHO.
  • XAI enhances the quality of personalized ART treatments by managing complex datasets.
  • Data was collected from 19,082 female participants in Poland and the UK between 2005-2023.
  • Optimal follicle sizes identified range from 13 to 20 mm for mature oocyte collection.
  • Findings show that intermediately sized follicles significantly enhance oocyte retrieval and embryo development.
“Intermediately sized follicles on the DoT were found to significantly contribute to the retrieval of mature oocytes and embryo development.”

This study highlights the potential of XAI techniques in optimizing IVF treatments, leading to better clinical outcomes.

item.title: Effects of Obesity on Survival Outcomes Following Cancer Diagnosis in Pediatric Patients - The ASCO Post
item.description: No summary available for this article. Click the link to read more.

item.title: What’s Going Around Right Now? The 4 Winter Viruses of the ‘Quad-Demic,’ Explained - Health.com
item.description:
What's Going Around Right Now? The 4 Winter Viruses of the 'Quad-Demic,' Explained

Date: January 5, 2025

Source: Health

Four illnesses are circulating at high levels this winter, leading to a 'quad-demic' in the U.S., significantly affecting public health and healthcare systems.

  • COVID-19, Influenza, RSV, and Norovirus are the major viruses currently affecting the population.
  • The CDC reports a record number of norovirus outbreaks this season.
  • Healthcare systems are strained due to the simultaneous spread of these viruses.
“It [has] a huge impact, not just on the individual who’s sick, but on the community.” - Geeta Sood, MD

Experts encourage individuals to take precautions, especially those who are at higher risk, to stay healthy this winter.

item.title: What’s behind joint pains this winter? Orthos and nutritionists tell you how to keep moving despite them - The Indian Express
item.description:
What’s behind joint pains this winter? Orthos and nutritionists tell you how to keep moving despite them

Date: January 13, 2025

Source: Indian Express

As the winter chill sets in, many people experience stiff and painful joints, limiting their ability to exercise. Experts explain that the cold can exacerbate swelling in tissues and bones, resulting in a decrease in range of motion and an increase in discomfort.

  • The cold can limit movement due to joint stiffness and pain.
  • Exposure to cold leads to constriction of blood vessels, reducing blood flow to limbs.
  • Swelling in bones and tissues during cold weather can increase discomfort.
"Is the cold limiting your movement because of stiff and painful joints?"

Understanding these factors is essential for managing and mitigating joint pain during the winter months.

item.title: What your walking speed can tell you about your health - Yahoo Life
item.description:
What Your Walking Speed Can Tell You About Your Health

Published: October 2023, Source: Yahoo Life

Walking is not only a low-impact activity that breaks sedentary time but can also serve as a vital sign of health. Understanding walking speed is important as it can indicate physical and cognitive health problems.

  • Walking is an accessible form of exercise that positively impacts health in various ways.
  • Vital signs, including walking speed, provide insights into physiological functioning.
  • The average walking speed varies by age and biological sex.
  • Studies show a strong correlation between walking speed and overall health.
  • Brisk walking can enhance cardiovascular health and support physical fitness.
  • Different types of walking, such as interval and mindful walking, offer unique benefits.
“Walking speed is strongly related to how well your brain is working.” - Peggy Cawthon

Incorporating walking into daily routines enhances overall health and could potentially lead to increased longevity.

item.title: Why do headaches worsen in the winter season? 5 remedies to treat them - The Times of India
item.description:
Why do headaches worsen in the winter season? 5 remedies to treat them

Publication Date: Not specified Source: Not specified

Headaches often intensify during the winter months due to various factors including changes in temperature and humidity. This article provides insights into why this happens and suggests five remedies to alleviate headache pain.

  • Winter weather can trigger headaches due to low pressure and cold temperatures.
  • Common types of winter headaches include sinus headaches and tension headaches.
  • Staying hydrated is crucial as dehydration can worsen headaches.
  • Over-the-counter pain relievers and rest can be effective treatments.
  • Consulting a healthcare professional is recommended for severe or persistent headaches.
“Headaches can be a common winter complaint, but understanding the triggers can help in managing them effectively.”

In conclusion, recognizing the winter triggers of headaches and employing these remedies can significantly help in managing discomfort during the colder months.

item.title: Want to stop smoking? $700 in rewards can really help, study says - The Jerusalem Post
item.description:
Want to stop smoking? $700 in rewards can really help, study says

Publication Date: JANUARY 14, 2025

Source: The Jerusalem Post

This article discusses a study led by the University of East Anglia that investigates the effectiveness of monetary rewards in aiding individuals, particularly pregnant women, to quit smoking. The findings suggest that financial incentives significantly improve cessation rates.

  • A collaborative study involving the University of East Anglia, University of Oxford, University of Edinburgh, and University of Massachusetts Amherst.
  • Research explored the effects of cash, vouchers, or deposits as incentives.
  • Results indicate that rewards increased the likelihood of quitting smoking among participants.
  • High certainty evidence shows that incentives are effective for pregnant women, with a greater success rate.
  • The study examined 48 prior studies with over 21,900 participants and found consistent results.
  • Success rates hold even after rewards are stopped.
“These findings show that financial incentives during pregnancy can more than double the chances of quitting smoking.” - Professor Linda Bauld

The study implies ongoing support for incentive schemes for smoking cessation, particularly for vulnerable populations like pregnant women.

item.title: Deadly 'zombie deer' disease could evolve to affect humans, warn scientists - The Times of India
item.description:
Deadly 'zombie deer' disease could evolve to affect humans, warn scientists

Publication Date: [Date not provided] Source: Daily Mail

Scientists have issued a warning that the incurable prion disease, known as the 'zombie deer' disease, could potentially evolve to affect humans, posing a serious threat of a new pandemic.

  • The disease, known scientifically as Chronic Wasting Disease (CWD), primarily affects deer and related species.
  • There are concerns it could jump to feral pigs and possibly domestic swine, affecting the swine market.
  • Symptoms include drooling, confusion, aggression, and weight loss, appearing about a year after infection.
  • Currently reported in at least 33 states, including Wyoming, Wisconsin, Colorado, and areas of Pennsylvania.
  • Health officials emphasize the importance of awareness, as the disease can spread through bodily fluids.
Dr. Michael Osterholm stated, "If they can get infected, surely it's possible domestic swine could also become infected? What would that do to the swine market? What would that do to the cattle market? These are huge issues."

Scientists stress the urgency of understanding and preparing for potential health crises that could arise from this disease spreading to humans.

item.title: China reports a novel virus from 252 patients infected by tick bites - Firstpost
item.description: No summary available for this article. Click the link to read more.

item.title: Iron next in line for fortification focus - FoodNavigator.com
item.description:
Iron Next in Line for Fortification Focus

Publication Date: October 2024 | Source: Food Navigator

This article discusses the increasing trends in women's health focusing on iron fortification in food and beverages, spurred by new research emphasizing the importance of iron during pregnancy.

  • The global market for women's health has reached $35.02bn and is expected to grow.
  • Research indicates that iron deficiency in pregnant women is a critical health concern, affecting around 32 million women worldwide.
  • A third-trimester iron infusion has been shown to significantly reduce anaemia.
  • The World Health Organization recommends oral iron tablets for pregnant women, but fortified foods could offer an alternative solution.
  • The fortified food market is valued at $103.54bn, driven by consumer demand for nutrient-enhanced products.
“While anaemia is one of the most avoidable causes of illness and death in resource-poor nations, any woman across the world can become anaemic during pregnancy.” - Professor Sant-Rayn Pasricha

The focus on iron fortification reflects a growing awareness of nutritional needs during pregnancy and could lead to innovative product development in the food industry.

item.title: 5 warning signs of fatty liver that appear on face - India.com
item.description:
5 Warning Signs of Fatty Liver That Appear on Your Face

Publication Date: January 14, 2025 Source: India.com

This article identifies five facial signs that may indicate the presence of fatty liver disease, highlighting the importance of recognizing these symptoms early for health management.

  • Pigmentation: Due to high insulin resistance, excess buildup leads to skin folds and pigmentation.
  • Itching: Impaired liver function affects bile salts, causing itching on the face.
  • Rosacea: A skin condition characterized by redness and the presence of white bumps.
  • Puffiness: High fatty liver levels impair liver's protein-making capacity, leading to a puffy face.
  • Rash: NAFLD patients may experience reduced zinc absorption, causing small bumps and skin irritation.
“Thanks For Reading!”

This article is a reminder to pay attention to our bodies and recognize possible health indicators that warrant further investigation.

item.title: Asymptomatic lung abscess of aspergillus in a female without previous lung diseases or immunocompromise: a case report - BMC Infectious Diseases
item.description:
Asymptomatic lung abscess of aspergillus in a female without previous lung diseases or immunocompromise: a case report

Published: 14 January 2025 | Source: BMC Infectious Diseases

This case report documents an unusual occurrence of a chronic lung abscess due to Aspergillus terreus in a 43-year-old female patient without immunocompromise or any structural lung disease, illustrating significant challenges in diagnosis due to the absence of symptoms.

  • The patient had a mass shadow detected on CT imaging without respiratory complaints.
  • 30 ml of purulent fluid aspirated from the lung confirmed an Aspergillus terreus infection.
  • Standard antifungal treatment resulted in a favorable outcome.
“Aspergillus lung abscess can occasionally occur in a person without pre-existent lung cavity and immune suppression.”

This case highlights the complexity of diagnosing fungal infections, especially in asymptomatic patients, and urges careful consideration of laboratory methods like mNGS for accurate identification.

item.title: American Medical Association suggests realistic health goals in 2025 - Medical Xpress
item.description:
American Medical Association Suggests Realistic Health Goals for 2025

Date: January 14, 2025, Source: Atlanta Journal-Constitution

As the new year approaches, the American Medical Association (AMA) encourages people to set effective wellness goals through simple, sustainable changes.

  • Move more, watch less: Substitute screen time with daily walks; aim for 150 minutes of moderate activity weekly.
  • Sayonara, processed foods: Turn meal prep into a family bonding experience to promote better dietary choices.
  • Prioritize quality rest: Aim for at least 7.5 hours of sleep per night and manage stress effectively.
  • Tech-smart health monitoring: Utilize validated health devices and online health screening tools to monitor health more effectively.
"Even small, positive choices you make now can have a big impact on your long-term well-being." - AMA President Bruce A. Scott

In summary, the AMA's suggestions focus on attainable habits to enhance overall health and well-being in 2025.
